data.text: ZIPP 303 Firecrest or ZIPP 303S?

Okay... obviously too much time on my hands. My hopes are the graphic will bring more attention to my first world problem. Please read entire post before responding. The ‚ùì is would you spend the extra $600 and get the 303 Firecrest over the 303 S? Bare in mind that I have a philosophy about purchases like this. And not settling, and then later regretting not spending the extra $. A conundrum as I feel stuck in this decision. Flipping a ü™ô perhaps may be easier. Current wheelset on my Bearclaw Thunderhawk is nearing it's end just a bit earlier than I was ready for. I don't have a lot of time to build something up and try to even build a custom wheelset. So with that in mind I had looked over Hunt as well as many others. In the end, the availability and the warranty has me as Zipp. Without getting into every single piece of gear on the rig, I'll just say that overall I try not to carry the kitchen sink. And much of the bikepacking I do is here in the desert southwest. Where one moment I could be on gravel stretches for countless miles, and then asphalt intermittently connecting. So...either wheel works. Not looking for advice on other wheelsets as I'd prefer to stay on topic of these two wheelsets. But I also think it would be ridiculous not to hear those as well. But preference is to decide on these two wheelsets. As I sit here, I feel slightly rushed as I don't know honestly how much more life my current wheelset has left. Ordering on Friday, so I have a few more days. Thanks in advance for taking the time to respond.
303s great value. Can take a beating.
data.author: Mike Buenaventura

data.text: I've ridden both, the weight difference is noticeable on accelerations. At speed there wasn't much difference noticeable. The Firecrest's are noticeably better in a cross wind. It's a hard choice, but I don't regret buying the Firecrest(I got the S's with a bike purchase)
data.author: Cory Rood

data.text: I was concerned about "cross wind". Especially in portions of the desert out here. Would that of pushed you in either direction?
data.author: Masumi Herota

data.text: not really, the difference still justifies the cost difference. it's a hard choice for sure
data.author: Cory Rood

data.text: Tbh both a great wheelsets and I think you'd be hard pushed when riding to tell them apart, I'd go 303s to save the extra spend. I have the 303s on a Gravel bike and 404 Firecrest on a Bianchi.. cant feel any noticable rolling difference.
data.author: Cameron Jones

data.text: Are you going to be going fast enough often enough that it's worth spending the money on the Firecrests (which should have slightly better aero)?
data.author: Steve Fuller

data.text: I asked myself that same question actually. As it's a legitimate piece in deciding whether to grab the Firecrest. I'd say yes. Especially on these desert roads and the fact that I pack minimally anyways. Or those days that I'm just doing a shortish adventure out here in the desert. It's certainly always up for debate when you count those days when you're not in need of aero .
data.author: Masumi Herota

data.text: seems like they save maybe 5W at fairly high speeds. Not enough for me to spend the extra $$ personally. That's your call tho
data.author: Steve Fuller

data.text: I saw that. Aero for me isnt the dominant factor. Wider internal. Better hubs (although they are new for Zipp so time will tell). Small weight reduction. It all adds up I guess. Does it add up to $600? That's my quandary. I don't utilize Facebook much to be honest... except for these kinds of things...groups. So everyones input certainly helps. Thanks Steve
data.author: Masumi Herota

data.text: 303s...
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: cant say much on the firecrest but i do have a pair of 303S‚Äôs and i love them. they are on my TT bike and i am 100% getting a second set for my gravel rig as soon as i can. comfy, durable, and easy to maintain.
data.author: Tiger Paton

data.text: Fwiw, internal rim widths are 23 for the 303s and 25 for firecrest. Idk what size tires you're running but the firecrests can handle a little larger width.
data.author: David R Pletcher

data.text: It ranges. And either wheelset will work. The Firecrest is probably a little more flush with the 42 to 45 that I usually run. Replaced seatbag with a Tubus Airy rear rack. That rack gives me better flexibility, but limits me to about 45.
data.author: Masumi Herota

data.text: Neither, for the same outlay you can get equivalent rims from overseas built up with way better hubs than the Zipps.
data.author: Jeremy Theys

data.text: I agree on the hubs. But Asia isn't going to have a Zipp warranty.
data.author: Masumi Herota

data.text: I‚Äôm not going to argue any warranty. Some people like a warranty, and that trumps savings. I‚Äôll take the $500 up front savings and have a better wheelset overall, and replace a rim in the future if needed. I can buy 3 replacement rims for the up front savings.
data.author: Jeremy Theys

data.text: like what? Not to hijack if you want to PM me
data.author: Kobi Voshell

data.text:
got a set of these that work great on gravel built up with White ind CLDs. https://novemberbicycles.com/products/all-road-35-26i. Also have a set of Light Bicycle WR 38 rims on CK R45 hubs that are solid. Both in the range of the zipps, but far less than a set of firecrests.
All Road 35-25i
novemberbicycles.com
data.author: Jeremy Theys

data.text: Firecrest just cause they look way better hehe

data.text: Good answer...ha...üôÇüåµüèúÔ∏è

data.text: It's a factor for sure. Just wish they didn't have those flimsy decals. They should've done like the 303s and had no decals.
data.author: Masumi Herota

data.text: They‚Äôre going on a Ti bike, spend that extra $600 or you‚Äôll hate yourself later.
data.author: Jason Geer

data.text: I like you're reasoning...lots of ti on the Bearclaw. Tubus Airy (titanium rear rack), silca ti Waterbottle Cages, King Manythings Ti cargo cages up front, and everywhere I could stick a Ti bolt...it does seem like the Zipp 303 S wouldn't fitüòÇü§™üåµüåé
data.author: Masumi Herota

data.text: I owned 303s abs 303 firecrest. Sold the 303s, because I never rode the S. Firecrest have taken a beating and held up to my size 6‚Äô4, 225 lbs.
data.author: Jason Holzworth

data.text: You will not regret the 303s one bit. If you really want to do it right contact Speed Vision Bikes and have Ryan build you the proper custom set you really want.
data.author: Dan Cable

data.text:
Just contact at speedvisionbikes.com. He‚Äôll set ya straight, box em up and get ‚Äòem out to ya. Done, now go ride!
Speed Vision Bikes - Bicycles, Bicycle Repair
speedvisionbikes.com
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: I‚Äôve owned both and firecrest every time, lighter, much better hubs and engagement, they can take an absolute battering and they look much better, I also run 404 FC on my road bike and the ride from them is stunning.
data.author: Tom Rea

data.text: üî• crest
data.author: Wade Gregory

data.text: It is pretty clear that you want the FCs, and they are materially better (hubs, width) so the question is budgetary. Will 600 dollars matter to you over the span of owning the wheels? Will it stop you from spending 600 dollars on something else you wanted?
data.author: Pat Yongpradit

data.text: For this kind of money a serious wheelbuilder will by far exceed both products. It's easy to outperform the 303s hubs on the same budget and it's easy to outperform the build on the Firecrest with the same budget.
data.author: Xaver von Treyer

data.text: care to share an example of such better wheel that is custom built vs the stock FC?
data.author: Cory Rood

data.text: You can build a set with Carbon Ti hubs, Sapim CX Super spokes and a great 40mm 25mm hookless rim for roughly ‚Ç¨ 1300 and end up sub 1300gr. I built myself a gravelset comparable to the Enve G23s with Dt Swiss 240 hubs and Sapim Superspokes that clocks in at 1170gr and cost half of what G23s would cost. I am just saying: talk to your local wheelbuilder and get much better quality for less money plus you get to pick every detail (judiging by the graphic you seem detail oriented ;-P)
data.author: Xaver von Treyer

data.text: see my link above as well. I don't want to bash the OP options as I'm sure both Zipp wheelsets are great, but moreso giving additional options to chew on.
data.author: Jeremy Theys

data.text: what rims? Just because they are the same depth doesn‚Äôt mean they are the same. Actual rim shape is equally as important as it‚Äôs depth.
data.author: Cory Rood

data.text: November all Road 35s. They were listed as 38s, so may not be exact same profile now, but close.
data.author: Jeremy Theys
Jeremy Theys

data.text: And Light Bicycle WR38s.
data.author: Jeremy Theys

data.text: is there any drag info on those hoops?
data.author: Cory Rood

data.text: I have no clue, and frankly not going to look as it will all be marketing speak. I know both of these are remarkable wheelsets that have been bulletproof on gravel so far. Both built up with CX-Ray spokes and great hubs. Couldn't be happier. Both equivalent price as the 303S, and far less than a set of Firecrests.

data.author: Jeremy Theys

data.text: Thanks for sharing...I did play around with it a bit. Since my initial posting (I started this post), I'm steering towards the Zipp Firecrest. However I can see where these guys have done their job to create a great degree of flexibility all the way down to the warranty.
data.author: Masumi Herota

data.text: you can‚Äôt go wrong with any of them.
data.author: Jeremy Theys

data.text: ‚ö†Ô∏èI'm the originator of this post. Want to say that you to everyone whom took the time to respond. Lots of great feedback. It was a difficult decision as originally I was going to build up a custom wheelset. And it may be the most expensive purchase outside of purchasing a frameset. It came down to so many parts. Zipp's warranty was a big one. As well as the internal width. Most of the time aero isn't a factor out there, but sometimes it is when I'm flying through the surrounding desert here where I live. üëâThe final decision (fork over $ today).... üõûZipp 303 Firecrest
data.author: Masumi Herota

data.text: great choice. You will love them. Prepare for smooth rides.
